Easter Meditations II

Circulation Manager
GEORGE W. LA MONT,'32:

I do not know that I qualify, but
a friend has forwarded me a pamphlet advertising an apparently phenomenal volume on "Woman—Her
Sex and Love Life." One page recounts the chapter titles. After listing such topics as: "Why a Misstep in a Girl is More Serious Than
in a Boy"; "The Female Sex Organs; Their Anatomy"; "Illegitimate Motherhood"; "The Girl Who
Lost Her Virginity"; "Dainty Underwear"; "Simultaneous Loves
Possible ;" "Love in the Life of
People of High Culture"; "Conception and Abortion Radically
ImpresDifferent"; "Maternal
sions"; "Syphilis" and "Venereal
Prophy-Laxis",—after listing all of
these, I say—the author (the great
but mysterious Dr. Robinson) finally comes to "Promiscuous Kissing."
In other words the chronological
order suggests that a young girl
(unprotected) who has done what
Freud suspects she would like to
do, become a mother without a franchise granted by God, worn salacious underwear, loved two persons
simultaneously and as a result of
her—to be poetic—indiscretions gotten the worst of things, has succeeded to such a state of ignominy
that she now must be shielded from
"Promiscous Kissing." Such a
metaphysical conception of sin can
only be rivalled by that of the Hopkins Student Council which having
been originally commissioned to prevent intellectual larceny on the Hopkins campus, exhausts all of its
energies providing an audience for
incompetent assembly entertainers.

EDITORIALS

T

BANQUET SEASON?
the junior banquet set for April 23, a lively week followWITH
ing that date may well be predicted due to the fact that there
the freshman and

have been no hostilities of any sort between
sophomore classes to date this year. Although the Student Council
ruling that there will be no breaking up of banquets is still in effect,
it is probable that the members of the two classes will find other ways
to work out their pent up energy.
Unless the council takes some action, it is to be expected that a considerable amount of damage will be done during this period—both to
property in vicinity of the University and to the class members themserves. When one starts out to completely eliminate the rah-rah' element from a college, it is necessary that no opportunity be given the
men to exhibit their animal instincts.
To give these individuals one such chance as this is much more dangerous than allowing some sort of hostilites throughout the entire college year. If freshman regulations and the interclass contests that go
with them are to be abolished, it would be wise to abolish banquet
fights as well.
There is no half way measure in this problem. It is necessary to definitely follow one course or the other. The present trend is, of course,
to remove all forms of class competition from the Homewood campus.
If this be stingently enforced, it is probable that during the course
of years every trace of the 'motion picture' type of college will be removed. Whether or not this is the wish of the students, will be seen
when the result of the vote on freshman regulations is announced by
the Student Council. It is needless to say that what the students wish is
not always what is best for them. However, when there is a question
as to which course the authorities should follow, it would seem that
some heed should be paid to the opinion of the majority of the student
body.

WHY THE DELAY?
it is very regretFROM the point of view of the athleticof authorities
Physical Education has not

able that the report of the committee
yet been submitted to Board of Trustees. With the general public under the impression that football has been abolished at Hopkins, it is
vitally necessary to the future of athletics that the decision be announced. Should the board decide to abolish football, it could not place
the authorities in any more disagreeable position than they are in at the
present writing. The question is one of such importance that a hasty decision should not be made, but in view of the necessity of some statement in the near future it would seem that greater effort could be exerted to bring the question before the board.

lege. His name was Sweeney.
Sweeney was an apollo. Or rather
he was 95 per cent apollo for he had
a cast in one eye. He was still,
however, an immensely romantic fellow. He was wont to strut up and
down Charles Street—always manipulating his neck so that the evileye shifted from the level of a second story window to the deep blue,
romanticS sky above. Thus you
caught only a fleeting glimpse of the
evil-eye. He was still, however, an
immensely romantic fellow.
But how was such a romantic
person to die? Was it to be at the
end of a rusty sword somewhere in
Arabia? Was it to be under the
hoofs of a thundering herd in Arizona? Was it to be after a slammed
door, a tearing of flimsy pajamas
and a fall from a bouduoir of the
fiftieth story to the walks below?
No. Sweeney got a sore throat
three years ago this May. A physician came, and looked down
Sweeney's throat. There was no
doubt about it. Sweeney had tonsilitis. With the dawn of a fifth
day after, the romance, the evil-eye
and English instructor SWeeney
were no more.
IV.
I take pride, perhaps, in exotic
things. For instance, I am most
supremely happy that I am the
only Hopkins student who is convinced that the last Barnstormer
production was offensive even as
fourth-rate drama. I am profoundly conceited that I was the first
student to arrive at the conclusion
that the Liberal Club is not liberal.
I am among the few, I believe,
who feel that the average Hopkins
student is an ass. I am elated over
the fact that it is my lot to believe
that at least half of the faculty
are no better than the average student. I was the only Hopkins student, I venture to say, who rode
down Charles Street on Easter Sunday in a suit three years old and a
heard that had a two-day start.
V.
Whatever may be the force that
motivates an entering student to
join a fraternity, it certainly cannot be one of friendship. I admit
that I am hardly an authority on
what the personality books call the
Art Of Making Friends, but if
friends are made by corraling a
group of freshmen into a house and
then by selecting half for friends in
a more or less haphazard fashion,
then I hope I have an inexhaustible supply of enemies. Doubtless,
residence in a fraternity house is
preferable to the primitive conditions of the dormitories, but when
one considers that seventy-five per
cent of the people in the world
aren't fit to live with anyway, I think
a tent in Wyman's Park would have
its advantages.

Two Orchestras Definitely Hired

The feature of the week is to
be the Ball, at which Guy Lombardo and his Royal Canadians
will furnish music. The affair is
to be held in the Lord Baltimore
Hotel on Monday June 8th. The
only other orchestra definitely
hired is T. Worth Murphy's
group, which plays at the Belvedere Hotel. This orchestra is to
be at the Night Club party, which
is to be held at Levering on June
4th.
Although prices in each individual affair have not been set, a
ticket to all activities will cost
$12.50. These tickets are to go
on sale soon at the post-office. According to members of the committee, the sum of the prices for
each individual event would total
about $22. Undergraduates are

t1

Deposit Not Required

New Schedule For June Week
Will Probably Be Carried Out

After several changes in the
original plans for June Week, the
committee has arranged a tentative schedule which, according to
Chairman Yellott, will probably
be carried out. Ten events are
on the program, which runs from
June 3rd to the 9th, starting with
the last Cotillion, and ending with
Commencement exercises at the
Lyric and the Senior Banquet at
the Southern Hotel.

Programs On Sale

Orders for the June Week
souvenir programs are being
taken at the post-office. These
are the only official programs,
and are selling at $1 per copy,
two for $1.50. They will be obtainable by order only.
The programs is to have a

of Gilman Hall tower in blue.
There will be about 15 pages,
each containing a picture. Among
these photographs will be pictures of the campus, and of the
sponsors for the various Senior affairs.
Schedule Has 10 Events

schedules is as follows:
Wednesday, June 3—Last Cotillion, place undecided.
Thursday, June 4—Beach Party, probably at
Maga Vista.
Friday, June 5—Night Club Party, at Levering Hall, T. Worth Murphy's Orchestra.
Saturday, June 6—Lacrosse game (afternoon),
at Homewood.
Afternoon—Tea Dance at Levering after
gzme.
Evening—Lacrosse Ball, place undecided.

Tuesday, June 9—Graduation at Lyric. Senior

SCHAALIANA
Preface: To edit the works of
E. A. Schaal in a sympathetic, understanding fashion is a hard but
delightful task. For fear that even
one person may have missed the
philosophy that Mr. Schaal has been
unloading in the "Y" news for the
past year, there have been grouped
below a few of the outstanding tidbits. They were chosen because of
their powers of stimulating the emotions and, of course, their complete
asininity.—H. L. F.

Nov., 1930.—A Sunday School
class composed of Goucher and
Hopkins students recently engaged
in a discussion of prayer. One
Goucher girl supported by a Hopkins student, vigorously supported
the theory that one might well pray
for rain during such a drought as
we have been having.
Life Made Easy Nov., 1930.—Dr. Howard A.
Kelly, at the University- Supper
Club, stated that a man's answer to
the question "What think ye of
Christ ?" is the irrlost important decision one makes, and will make possible the solution of all other problems of life.
Very Psychological, Very Metaphysical,'Very Extraordinary

December 12, 1930.—When is
one religious? . . . To be religious
it would seem, does not necessarily
imply the acceptance of any particular set of dogmas or creeds, although religious people often do
this. The Y. M. C. A. recognizes
that many religious souls both
among the students and faculty seem
to derive great satisfaction . . .
by keeping up a continuous barrage
of criticism against the church, the
Y. M. C. A., many types of pious
living, etc., etc.

INTERCOLLEGIATE
NEWS
Fraternities at the University of
Wisconsin are facing serious difficulties as a result of the,raising of
the scholastic standards.
* * *
A New York branch of Yale University to be established at the Hotel
Biltmore College is the novel solution offered by one of Yale alumnus for the "Week-end habit" so
prevalent at Eastern universities.
* * *
"It is my belief that the true purpose of education is to stimulate
ideas, to preserve and to promote
ideals. I do not believe that education can be thrust upon a person
by 'forcible feeding.' Mental food
is like physical food. People won't
take much of it unless they have
an appetite for it. I hope that, in
this university, we can create such
an appetite, make our students mentally hungry," says Walter Williams, President of the University of
Missouri, and formerly dean of its
school of journalism.
*
Jose Padin, commissioner of education of Porto Rico, has planned
a graduate school of tropical agriculture for the University of Porto
Rico, and negotiations are already
being carried on toward this end
with Cornell University.
* * *
Only 16 per cent of the teachers
employed in North Carolina schools
during the 1928-29 year were men.
* * *
Dr. H. W. McCastline, medical
officer of Columbia University,
states that the typical Columbia
freshman does not smoke; drinks
two or more glasses of milk daily;
regularly eats his spinach and lettuce, and prefers swimming as a
sport.
*
*
Violent anti-Semitic demonstrations at Pecs University last Tuesday resulted in eight Jewish students
being so severely injured that they
had to be taken to a hospital.

This coming Saturday the Hopkins lacrosse squad will meet
Swarthmore College at Homewood field. As a result of the latter's weak performance against
Mt. Washington two weeks ago,
Dr. Van Orman does not expect
his squad to encounter much stiff
opposition.
Swarthmore Men Inexperienced

Due to the infertile stage of the
development of lacrosse in Pennsylvania, most of the members of
the Swarthmore team do not have
the experience of Black and Blue
teams. However, the Maroon
team possesses on the attack a
stellar performer in Pike. He
happens to be a former Friends'
School player and is the pivot of
the Swarthmore offense. The

128 W. Fayette Street

two points that the maroon tal-

lied against the Hillmen were
both scored by Pike.
Maroons Possess Fight

On the defense the Maroons
are again hampered by the inexperience of their material; but
the team does possess plenty of
fight. This was particularly evident during the second period of
the Mt. Washington contest. The
Hillmen, possessing some of the
finest material in the state, had
to put forth their best efforts to
score.
For the Jays, this game should
prove a good opportunity to
smooth a few rough edges. Likewise it will add to the team's experience.

GEORGE W. LA MONT,'32:

I do not know that I qualify, but
a friend has forwarded me a pamphlet advertising an apparently phenomenal volume on "Woman—Her
Sex and Love Life." One page recounts the chapter titles. After listing such topics as: "Why a Misstep in a Girl is More Serious Than
in a Boy"; "The Female Sex Organs; Their Anatomy"; "Illegitimate Motherhood"; "The Girl Who
Lost Her Virginity"; "Dainty Underwear"; "Simultaneous Loves
Possible ;" "Love in the Life of
People of High Culture"; "Conception and Abortion Radically
ImpresDifferent"; "Maternal
sions"; "Syphilis" and "Venereal
Prophy-Laxis",—after listing all of
these, I say—the author (the great
but mysterious Dr. Robinson) finally comes to "Promiscuous Kissing."
In other words the chronological
order suggests that a young girl
(unprotected) who has done what
Freud suspects she would like to
do, become a mother without a franchise granted by God, worn salacious underwear, loved two persons
simultaneously and as a result of
her—to be poetic—indiscretions gotten the worst of things, has succeeded to such a state of ignominy
that she now must be shielded from
"Promiscous Kissing." Such a
metaphysical conception of sin can
only be rivalled by that of the Hopkins Student Council which having
been originally commissioned to prevent intellectual larceny on the Hopkins campus, exhausts all of its
energies providing an audience for
incompetent assembly entertainers.

EDITORIALS

T

BANQUET SEASON?
the junior banquet set for April 23, a lively week followWITH
ing that date may well be predicted due to the fact that there
the freshman and

have been no hostilities of any sort between
sophomore classes to date this year. Although the Student Council
ruling that there will be no breaking up of banquets is still in effect,
it is probable that the members of the two classes will find other ways
to work out their pent up energy.
Unless the council takes some action, it is to be expected that a considerable amount of damage will be done during this period—both to
property in vicinity of the University and to the class members themserves. When one starts out to completely eliminate the rah-rah' element from a college, it is necessary that no opportunity be given the
men to exhibit their animal instincts.
To give these individuals one such chance as this is much more dangerous than allowing some sort of hostilites throughout the entire college year. If freshman regulations and the interclass contests that go
with them are to be abolished, it would be wise to abolish banquet
fights as well.
There is no half way measure in this problem. It is necessary to definitely follow one course or the other. The present trend is, of course,
to remove all forms of class competition from the Homewood campus.
If this be stingently enforced, it is probable that during the course
of years every trace of the 'motion picture' type of college will be removed. Whether or not this is the wish of the students, will be seen
when the result of the vote on freshman regulations is announced by
the Student Council. It is needless to say that what the students wish is
not always what is best for them. However, when there is a question
as to which course the authorities should follow, it would seem that
some heed should be paid to the opinion of the majority of the student
body.

WHY THE DELAY?
it is very regretFROM the point of view of the athleticof authorities
Physical Education has not

able that the report of the committee
yet been submitted to Board of Trustees. With the general public under the impression that football has been abolished at Hopkins, it is
vitally necessary to the future of athletics that the decision be announced. Should the board decide to abolish football, it could not place
the authorities in any more disagreeable position than they are in at the
present writing. The question is one of such importance that a hasty decision should not be made, but in view of the necessity of some statement in the near future it would seem that greater effort could be exerted to bring the question before the board.

lege. His name was Sweeney.
Sweeney was an apollo. Or rather
he was 95 per cent apollo for he had
a cast in one eye. He was still,
however, an immensely romantic fellow. He was wont to strut up and
down Charles Street—always manipulating his neck so that the evileye shifted from the level of a second story window to the deep blue,
romanticS sky above. Thus you
caught only a fleeting glimpse of the
evil-eye. He was still, however, an
immensely romantic fellow.
But how was such a romantic
person to die? Was it to be at the
end of a rusty sword somewhere in
Arabia? Was it to be under the
hoofs of a thundering herd in Arizona? Was it to be after a slammed
door, a tearing of flimsy pajamas
and a fall from a bouduoir of the
fiftieth story to the walks below?
No. Sweeney got a sore throat
three years ago this May. A physician came, and looked down
Sweeney's throat. There was no
doubt about it. Sweeney had tonsilitis. With the dawn of a fifth
day after, the romance, the evil-eye
and English instructor SWeeney
were no more.
IV.
I take pride, perhaps, in exotic
things. For instance, I am most
supremely happy that I am the
only Hopkins student who is convinced that the last Barnstormer
production was offensive even as
fourth-rate drama. I am profoundly conceited that I was the first
student to arrive at the conclusion
that the Liberal Club is not liberal.
I am among the few, I believe,
who feel that the average Hopkins
student is an ass. I am elated over
the fact that it is my lot to believe
that at least half of the faculty
are no better than the average student. I was the only Hopkins student, I venture to say, who rode
down Charles Street on Easter Sunday in a suit three years old and a
heard that had a two-day start.
V.
Whatever may be the force that
motivates an entering student to
join a fraternity, it certainly cannot be one of friendship. I admit
that I am hardly an authority on
what the personality books call the
Art Of Making Friends, but if
friends are made by corraling a
group of freshmen into a house and
then by selecting half for friends in
a more or less haphazard fashion,
then I hope I have an inexhaustible supply of enemies. Doubtless,
residence in a fraternity house is
preferable to the primitive conditions of the dormitories, but when
one considers that seventy-five per
cent of the people in the world
aren't fit to live with anyway, I think
a tent in Wyman's Park would have
its advantages.

Two Orchestras Definitely Hired

The feature of the week is to
be the Ball, at which Guy Lombardo and his Royal Canadians
will furnish music. The affair is
to be held in the Lord Baltimore
Hotel on Monday June 8th. The
only other orchestra definitely
hired is T. Worth Murphy's
group, which plays at the Belvedere Hotel. This orchestra is to
be at the Night Club party, which
is to be held at Levering on June
4th.
Although prices in each individual affair have not been set, a
ticket to all activities will cost
$12.50. These tickets are to go
on sale soon at the post-office. According to members of the committee, the sum of the prices for
each individual event would total
about $22. Undergraduates are

t1

New Schedule For June Week
Will Probably Be Carried Out

After several changes in the
original plans for June Week, the
committee has arranged a tentative schedule which, according to
Chairman Yellott, will probably
be carried out. Ten events are
on the program, which runs from
June 3rd to the 9th, starting with
the last Cotillion, and ending with
Commencement exercises at the
Lyric and the Senior Banquet at
the Southern Hotel.

Programs On Sale

Orders for the June Week
souvenir programs are being
taken at the post-office. These
are the only official programs,
and are selling at $1 per copy,

SCHAALIANA
Preface: To edit the works of
E. A. Schaal in a sympathetic, understanding fashion is a hard but
delightful task. For fear that even
one person may have missed the
philosophy that Mr. Schaal has been
unloading in the "Y" news for the
past year, there have been grouped
below a few of the outstanding tidbits. They were chosen because of
their powers of stimulating the emotions and, of course, their complete
asininity.—H. L. F.

Nov., 1930.—A Sunday School
class composed of Goucher and
Hopkins students recently engaged
in a discussion of prayer. One
Goucher girl supported by a Hopkins student, vigorously supported
the theory that one might well pray
for rain during such a drought as
we have been having.
Life Made Easy Nov., 1930.—Dr. Howard A.
Kelly, at the University- Supper
Club, stated that a man's answer to
the question "What think ye of
Christ ?" is the irrlost important decision one makes, and will make possible the solution of all other problems of life.
Very Psychological, Very Metaphysical,'Very Extraordinary

December 12, 1930.—When is
one religious? . . . To be religious
it would seem, does not necessarily
imply the acceptance of any particular set of dogmas or creeds, although religious people often do
this. The Y. M. C. A. recognizes
that many religious souls both
among the students and faculty seem
to derive great satisfaction . . .
by keeping up a continuous barrage
of criticism against the church, the
Y. M. C. A., many types of pious
living, etc., etc.

Fraternities at the University of
Wisconsin are facing serious difficulties as a result of the,raising of

A New York branch of Yale University to be established at the Hotel
Biltmore College is the novel solution offered by one of Yale alumnus for the "Week-end habit" so
prevalent at Eastern universities.
* * *
"It is my belief that the true purpose of education is to stimulate
ideas, to preserve and to promote
ideals. I do not believe that education can be thrust upon a person
by 'forcible feeding.' Mental food
is like physical food. People won't
take much of it unless they have
an appetite for it. I hope that, in
this university, we can create such
an appetite, make our students mentally hungry," says Walter Williams, President of the University of
Missouri, and formerly dean of its
school of journalism.
*
Jose Padin, commissioner of education of Porto Rico, has planned
a graduate school of tropical agriculture for the University of Porto
Rico, and negotiations are already
being carried on toward this end
with Cornell University.
* * *
Only 16 per cent of the teachers
employed in North Carolina schools
during the 1928-29 year were men.
* * *
Dr. H. W. McCastline, medical
officer of Columbia University,
states that the typical Columbia
freshman does not smoke; drinks
two or more glasses of milk daily;
regularly eats his spinach and lettuce, and prefers swimming as a
sport.

had to be taken to a hospital.

This coming Saturday the Hopkins lacrosse squad will meet
Swarthmore College at Homewood field. As a result of the latter's weak performance against
Mt. Washington two weeks ago,
Dr. Van Orman does not expect
his squad to encounter much stiff
opposition.
Swarthmore Men Inexperienced

Due to the infertile stage of the
development of lacrosse in Pennsylvania, most of the members of
the Swarthmore team do not have
the experience of Black and Blue
teams. However, the Maroon
team possesses on the attack a
stellar performer in Pike. He
happens to be a former Friends'
School player and is the pivot of
the Swarthmore offense. The

128 W. Fayette Street

two points that the maroon tal-

lied against the Hillmen were
both scored by Pike.
Maroons Possess Fight

On the defense the Maroons
are again hampered by the inexperience of their material; but
the team does possess plenty of
fight. This was particularly evident during the second period of
the Mt. Washington contest. The
Hillmen, possessing some of the
finest material in the state, had
to put forth their best efforts to
score.
For the Jays, this game should
prove a good opportunity to
smooth a few rough edges. Likewise it will add to the team's experience.

A new system of debating will
be tried here it was learned. It is
planned to employ three constructive speeches of ten minutes and
one rebuttal of eight minutes by
each team with no decision. Attire will be formal, and arrangements are being made for the
transportation of persons who
wish to make the trip. Officials
request that anyone desiring to
go to Frederick, and any member
of the Council and Club who will
have room for passengers, to drop
a note in P.O. Box 1172 immediately. Members of the team will
be chosen this week from among
Stanton, Brook, Doctofsky, Wasserman, Stark and Blum.
